results.abstract: Bits blog profiles Tiffany Montague, manager of space initiatives at Google, which already collects astronomical data and makes it available to the public; photo (M)
results.snippet: Google, as you may know, runs a search engine and sells ads. How odd then that Tiffany Montague works at the company.     Ms. Montague is the manager of Google's space initiatives -- overseeing things like sending robots to the moon and ogling Mars....
results.lead_paragraph: Google, as you may know, runs a search engine and sells ads. How odd then that Tiffany Montague works at the company. Ms. Montague is the manager of Google's space initiatives -- overseeing things like sending robots to the moon and ogling Mars. It's not exactly the stuff that keeps the lights on at the Googleplex, but this type of work seems to make Sergey Brin and Larry Page happy.

results.abstract: One of two critical cooling systems aboard International Space Station malfunctions, setting off alarms and triggering extensive reduction in power; mission managers give tentative approval to plans for complex two-spacewalk repair job (M)
results.snippet: One of two coolant systems aboard the International Space Station malfunctioned, setting off alarms.
results.lead_paragraph: One of two critical cooling systems aboard the International Space Station malfunctioned late on Saturday, setting off alarms and triggering an extensive reduction in power. Mission managers gave tentative approval on Sunday to plans for a complex two-spacewalk repair job late this week. The cooling system, which dissipates heat generated by the lab's electronics, initially shut down around 8 p.m. Eastern time on Saturday when a circuit breaker tripped, setting off warning alarms that awoke the crew. With reduced cooling, flight controllers were forced to shut down two of the space station's four stabilizing gyroscopes, used to help control the lab's orientation; one communications channel; and several computer control units.

results.abstract: Popular parenting blogs and Web sites indicate that noticeable number of New York city parents are looking for baby sitters and nannies to help their children learn second language, one they may not speak themselves; parents cite different reasons for hiring nannies and baby sitters to speak second language with their children; some believe it makes them smarter, but many parents have connection to another language and want to reinforce it; research shows that learning second language makes it easier to learn additional languages; photo (M)

headline.main: Bringing Up a Bilingual Child, With Help From the Baby Sitter

results.snippet: A growing number of New York City parents want caregivers to teach their children a language.
results.section_name: Technology; Front Page; Education; New York and Region
results.lead_paragraph: When Maureen Mazumder enrolled her daughter, Sabrina, in a Spanish singalong class a year ago, she hoped it would be the first step in helping her learn a second language. But the class did not seem to do the trick, so Ms. Mazumder decided to hire a baby sitter, one who would not only care for her daughter but also speak to her exclusively in Spanish. ''It was a must that she speak Spanish,'' said Ms. Mazumder, who said neither she nor her husband was fluent in the language. ''We feel so strongly that our daughter hear another language.''

results.snippet: READING FOR MARS, I: Mary Roach's jaunty exploration of space travel, ''Packing for Mars,'' plants its flag at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Will any astronauts be tossing it in their carry-ons? Some books have been launched into space. Ron...
results.lead_paragraph: READING FOR MARS, I: Mary Roach's jaunty exploration of space travel, ''Packing for Mars,'' plants its flag at No. 6 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Will any astronauts be tossing it in their carry-ons? Some books have been launched into space. Ron Garan, a NASA astronaut who is preparing to fly to the International Space Station in March, has been posting Twitter updates about the books he's taking along, including ''The Blue Sweater: Bridging the Gap Between Rich and Poor in an Interconnected World,'' by Jacqueline Novogratz, and Muhammad Yunus's ''Creating a World Without Poverty.'' He may also find some books left behind by previous travelers, including Goethe's ''Faust'' and Robert A. Heinlein's sci-fi classic ''The Moon Is a Harsh Mistress,'' carried up by the former Microsoft executive Charles Simonyi during his two self-financed voyages. Are there e-books in space? Astronauts do have iPods, according to Robert Pearlman, the editor of the space history Web site collectSPACE, but ''they are of the older, pre-touch-screen generation, and no Kindles, to my knowledge, have made their way to orbit as of yet.'' (Apparently, they have not yet been tested to make sure they don't release dangerous gases.) But astronauts do carry laptops, Pearlman added, and at least one book, ''Principles of Clinical Medicine for Space Flight,'' whose co-editor is the astronaut and physician Michael Barratt, has been read -- and revised -- digitally in orbit.

results.abstract: Iran's Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad unveils long-range unmanned bomber aircraft, latest in series of announcements about new Iranian military advances as tensions rise over Tehran's nuclear program (M)

headline.main: Iran's President Unveils New Long-Range Drone Aircraft

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: UNITED STATES DEFENSE AND MILITARY FORCES

results.snippet: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad called the long-range weapon an “ambassador of death” for Iran’s enemies.

byline.original: By WILLIAM YONG and ROBERT F. WORTH; William Yong reported from Tehran, and Robert F. Worth from Washington

results.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN -- Iran unveiled a long-range unmanned bomber on Sunday, the latest in a series of announcements about new Iranian military advances as tensions rise over Tehran's nuclear program. Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, at a ceremony to mark Iran's Defense Industry Day, called the weapon a ''messenger of glory and salvation for humanity'' but an ''ambassador of death'' for Iran's enemies.

results.abstract: Description of four boutiques opening up on Madison Avenue's retail strip: Hickoree's Hard Goods, Brunello Cucinelli, David Yurman and CH Carolina Herrera; photos; drawings (M)
results.snippet: TUMBLEWEEDS that rolled past the shuttered storefronts on upper Madison Avenue are finally clearing out. In recent months, a bevy of new boutiques has brought luster back to the shiny retail strip, most notably Lanvin (No. 815). More are on deck,...
results.lead_paragraph: TUMBLEWEEDS that rolled past the shuttered storefronts on upper Madison Avenue are finally clearing out. In recent months, a bevy of new boutiques has brought luster back to the shiny retail strip, most notably Lanvin (No. 815). More are on deck, including the first namesake boutique for the designer Reed Krakoff, who worked his magic on Coach (No. 831). And Ralph Lauren's gilded empire between East 71st and 72nd Streets is expanding, with a store devoted to his women's line and home now under construction (No. 888). 1 At HICKOREE'S HARD GOODS, ''We like products that evoke nostalgia for our childhood, like astronaut ice cream,'' said Emil Corsillo (pictured, left, with Sandy, his brother), who opened the store inside the just-opened, pine-fresh J. Crew Men's Shop. The Hickoree's shop, which occupies a former bank vault, began online and specializes in uncommon American-made products. Items include Hill-Side ties ($76); colorful Solmate socks (recycled materials, $19), canvas Mason bags ($79) and the Original Tree Swing (a slingshot, $21). The store is at 1040 Madison Avenue (79th Street); (212) 453-2677, hickorees.com.

results.abstract: Nick Kanas Op-Ed article suggests that insights from National Aeronautics and Space Administration research on effects of long-term confinement in small spaces could be useful to those attempting to help 33 Chilean miners trapped underground; proposes that miners and those on surface work as one team, following guidelines that have come out of NASA's research, until stifling days of confinement end (M)
results.snippet: NASA research on dealing with isolation in enclosed spaces could aid the Chilean miners who are likely to be trapped for months.
results.lead_paragraph: San Francisco FOR the past two decades, NASA has been studying what happens to people when they are enclosed in small spaces for long periods of time. The research has yielded insights that might be of use to the 33 Chilean miners, who are likely to be trapped underground for months.
